Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Assessing the Simulated Arctic Freshwater System in CMIP5 Models, the CESM Large Ensemble, and Forced Simulations
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Arctic freshwater (FW) system is likely to undergo considerable change in coming decades with downstream impacts on ocean circulation, climate, and ecosystems. An ability to understand and project these impacts, in turn, will have important socio-economic influences on fisheries, energy distribution, and reinsurance industries, amongst others. However, the reliability of climate projections is uncertain and there is only a limited understanding of the importance of natural variability in the midst of anthropogenically forced change. This project seeks to address these issues through a series of modeling experiments and comparison of the model results with observational and reanalysis data sets. This project will contribute to STEM workforce development through provision of support to a young, early-career, female PI during the formative years of her career and support for the training of a graduate student. The PI will leverage her connections with the National Center for Atmospheric Research to include project results in their outreach exhibits for the general public. Results will also be included in public talks and university lectures.


This project will investigate the following major science questions:
1. Do climate models show a consistent picture of projected Arctic Ocean FW changes during the 21st century and beyond? Are there obvious reasons for the model differences (e.g., resolution, sea ice model complexity, number of straits through the Canadian Arctic Archipelago, etc.)?
2. How large is the role of internal variability for different terms of the Arctic FW budget in climate simulations? How does this affect uncertainty in future projections at various timescales? How large does an ensemble need to be in order to capture the magnitude of internal variability?
3. How well do simulated FW components in Fram Strait and the switchyard region agree with observations from the last decade? What are the dynamics that lead to changes in FW from different sources?
To address these questions, first the Arctic Ocean freshwater (FW) budget in the suite of the Coupled Model Intercomparison Project Phase 5 (CMIP5) simulations for the 20th and 21st century will be assessed, followed by an analysis of the role of internal variability of terms of the Arctic FW budget in a large ensemble of simulations from the Community Earth System Model (CESM). Finally, the contribution of FW from different sources in Fram Strait and the Arctic switchyard region in the CESM will be compared with observations using new simulated FW tracers, and the Arctic Ocean dynamics leading to the variability of FW from different sources will be investigated. The Arctic Ocean FW budget has not been analyzed for the new generation of climate models participating in CMIP5, despite the changes that can be expected compared to CMIP3 due to the improvements to the simulation of the Arctic sea ice and the additional open passages in the Canadian Arctic Archipelago. The use of the large CESM ensemble provides an unique opportunity to assess the role of internal variability in terms of the Arctic FW budget, and comparisons to across-model scatter from CMIP5 will allow insight on the sources of uncertainty in future projections. Furthermore, the use of FW tracers in the CESM will allow a more detailed comparison with a new set of observations and will enable analysis of the dynamics that lead to the observed interannual variability of FW from different sources in two key regions in the Arctic.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We documented abrupt cold events in the North Atlantic (similar to those documented in proxy records during the Holocene) in a long, orbitally-forced transient simulation using the Community Climate System Model (Version 3). The cold events are characterized by surface ocean cooling and advances of sea ice (Klus et al., 2017). They were created by prolonged positive phase of the North Atlantic Oscillation (with deeper penetration of storms in the eastern Arctic Ocean) and associated increased in freshwater transport from the Arctic Ocean to the northern North Atlantic through the Fram Strait, followed by a collapse in deep-water formation in the northwestern Atlantic Ocean. Given the fact that an increased in CO2 concentration in the atmosphere is projected to result in a similar increase in fresh-water transport to the sub-polar gyre from Greenland melt  and the Arctic Ocean through Fram Strait, this implies that future warming may be punctuated by episodes of cooling in the North Hemisphere.   

Sea ice thickness in the Arctic is decreasing leading to increase in sea ice drift speed for the same wind forcing and increased in surface ocean stratification due to melt, two factors having opposite effects on vertical mixing of heat between the surface mixed-layer and warmer waters beneath the mixed-layer. The analysis of in-situ temperature and salinity vertical profiles from the field experiment AIDJEX (1975-1976) and from Ice tethered Profilers (ITP) buoys (2006-2012), two periods with very different surface stratification, clearly shows that the increased stratification – and therefore reduction in vertical mixing—dominates the response of the system. A comparison of the CESM-LE with the same in-situ observations from AIDJEX and ITPs shows that vertical mixing in CESM is too large with solar heat and salt transported deeper beneath the mixed-layer than in observations. This implies that heat of Pacific origin lying beneath the mixed-layer in the Canada Basin may be ventilated to the surface in this model, and exaggerate sea ice melt.  

The Arctic Ocean is considered a quiescent ocean with little vertical ocean heat fluxes between the warmer waters beneath the mixed-layer and the surface due to its high stratification. This view comes from the fact that in-situ observations are done over stable ice floe for logistic reasons. One exception includes measurements made during the Surface HEat Budget of the Arctic experiment in March 1998 when a lead was formed at the ice camp and where large (~400W/m2) vertical ocean heat fluxes were observed. Results from a high-resolution (1m) large eddy simulations (counter-intuitively) show that large vertical turbulent ocean heat fluxes between warmer waters beneath the mixed-layer and the surface are simulated when a negative ice-ocean stress curl (and downward Ekman pumping velocity) is present along a sea-ice lead rather than positive ice-ocean stress curl (and upward Ekman pumping velocity). This challenges the view of a quiescent Arctic Ocean and suggests that vertical exchanges of heat between warmer waters beneath the mixed-layer and the surface may be more important than previously thought. This is also important given that the large-scale atmospheric circulation associated with the semi-permanent Arctic High and Beaufort Gyre surface expression are anti-cyclonic (leading negative ice-ocean surface stress curl on average).

Bourgault, P., D. Straub, L.-P. Nadeau, K. Duquette and L.B. Tremblay, 2020: Vertical heat fluxes beneath idealized sea ice leads in large-eddy simulations: comparison with observations from the SHEBA experiment, Journal of Physical Oceanography, 50 (8), 2189-2202, doi.org/10.1175/JPO-D-19-0298.1.
